results.description:
[SYNTHETIC DATA FOR TESTING] A critical remote code execution vulnerability exists 
    in Visual Studio Code versions prior to 1.110.0. An attacker could exploit this 
    vulnerability by crafting a malicious workspace file that, when opened, allows 
    arbitrary code execution with the privileges of the current user.
results.solution: Update Visual Studio Code to version 1.110.0 or later. Download from https://code.visualstudio.com/

results.description:
[SYNTHETIC DATA FOR TESTING] A privilege escalation vulnerability exists in 
    Docker Desktop for macOS and Windows versions prior to 30.0.0. A local attacker 
    with low privileges could exploit this vulnerability to gain elevated privileges 
    on the host system through the Docker daemon.
results.solution: Update Docker Desktop to version 30.0.0 or later. Run: docker --version to check current version.

results.description:
[SYNTHETIC DATA FOR TESTING] A type confusion vulnerability in the V8 JavaScript 
    engine in Google Chrome versions prior to 145.0.0.0 allows a remote attacker to 
    potentially exploit heap corruption via a crafted HTML page.
results.solution: Update Google Chrome to version 145.0.0.0 or later. Chrome should auto-update, or go to Help > About Google Chrome.

results.description:
[SYNTHETIC DATA FOR TESTING] A local file inclusion vulnerability in Slack Desktop 
    application versions prior to 4.48.0 allows a local attacker to read arbitrary files 
    on the system by manipulating deep links.
results.solution: Update Slack to version 4.48.0 or later. The app should auto-update, or download from https://slack.com/downloads/

results.description:
[SYNTHETIC DATA FOR TESTING] An HTTP request smuggling vulnerability in Node.js 
    versions prior to 26.0.0 allows remote attackers to bypass security controls, 
    poison web caches, or perform credential hijacking via malformed HTTP requests.
results.solution: Update Node.js to version 26.0.0 or later. Run: node --version to check, then download from https://nodejs.org/

results.description:
[SYNTHETIC DATA FOR TESTING] A deserialization vulnerability in Python's pickle 
    module in versions prior to 3.10.0 could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary 
    code when unpickling untrusted data.
results.solution: Update Python to version 3.10.0 or later. Alternatively, avoid using pickle with untrusted data and use safer serialization formats like JSON.
